passages.text: India | Telecom Services
Indian Telecom | Takeaways from RIL AGM

At its AGM, RIL highlighted its success in FWA, an overhaul of its customer service potentially aimed at acquiring premium subscribers. Jio sees Enterprise segment as a key growth lever and has sounded its overseas aspirations too. Offerings like JioPC and Jio Al Cloud could help Jio drive non- connectivity revenues. Jio's listing in 1HCY26, bodes well for the sector's tariff outlook and may even drive a re- rating in telecom stocks in the run- up to the IPO.

Jio's listing bodes well for tariff outlook: At its AGM, RIL announced plans to list Jio Platforms in 1HCY26. Per our calculations, to offer a \(10\%\) IRR to its investors, Jio's market cap would need to be US \(118bn in Mar- 26. This would require its EBITDA to reach US\) 10bn by FY27 which in turn would need a \(20\%\) cumulative tariff hike from current levels even after assuming a \(2.4x\) jump in its non- mobile revenues over FY25- 27E to US \(2.8bn. This could bode well for all telcos, though Bharti Hexacom has the highest sensitivity to tariff interventions.

Service quality improvements aimed at gaining premium subscribers: RIL highlighted that Jio is redesigning every customer touch- point to improve customer service and delight their subscribers. We see this as an important ingredient to scale the postpaid and enterprise market. Jio's rising focus on customer service may indicate a rising focus gaining share among premium subscribers - something that Bharti Airtel has done very well.

Home Broadband additions ahead of expectations: RIL highlighted that its proprietary UBR technology, has enabled giga- bit speeds while avoiding cable- cut disruptions. JioAirFiber has become the largest fixed wireless broadband service in the world (added \(1m +\) homes/month). This is higher than the 10m additions we model in our home broadband assumptions.

Focus on scaling the enterprise segment: RIL highlighted that the enterprise segment will be the next growth lever for Jio. Given relatively smaller scale of enterprise business vs. peers, Jio has headroom to grow this business further. Unlocking the SME segment could become a large opportunity for Jio as its peers are more focused on larger corporates (FY25 India enterprise revenues - Bharti: Rs146bn, Tata Communications: Rs87bn).

Sounding overseas aspiration: Jio plans to expand overseas potentially offering its technology stack such as self- developed 5G core, UBR broadband technology and enterprise offerings around connectivity, Unified Collaboration, cloud services and IoT.

Moving beyond connectivity with Jio Al Cloud...: RIL highlighted that Jio Al Cloud - which was introduced last year and offered up to 100GB free cloud storage for all Jio users has gained over 40muses. RIL introduced an intelligence- layer on top of storage which allows quick and easy access to stored information. This move may offer Jio access to user- consented data which could have several direct/indirect monetization possibilities in the future.

...and JioPC: RIL also announced JioPC - which allows users to transform their TVs to a virtual Al- ready computer. This is an innovative way of cross- selling Infrastructure- as- a- Service to retail and SME users and may see reasonably decent pickup, if priced well, given that it will allow users to cut back on upfront spends on PCs/Laptops and will also allow them to upgrade/ downgrade hardware specifications as and when required.

We have valued R.Jio at US \(146bn EV in our SoTP: We believe R.Jio remains well- placed to deliver \(18\% /23\%\) CAGR in Revenues/EBITDA over FY25- 27, given rising tariffs in mobile and scale- up of home broadband business. We have valued Jio at an EV of US\) 146bn, assuming \(13x EV/EBITDA and US\) 130bn market cap, in our SoTP.
Akshat Agarwal, CFA \* | Equity Analyst

We would like to thank Harish Mundada, employee of Evaluerserve Inc., for providing research support services to our preparation of this report.

Our price target of Rs2,500 is SOTP- based. We assign a 14.0x EV/EBITDA multiple to the India mobile business and a 14.0x multiple to non- mobile and use our PT for Indus Towers and CMP for Airtel Africa to arrive at our price target. Downside risks: No tariff hikes, higher than expected capex, lower than expected 5G monetization and market share gains.

We value Bharti Hexacom at 16x 12m fwd EV/EBITDA to arrive at our PT of Rs 2,250. Key risks include related party transactions impacting future margins, further tariff hikes being delayed, lower quantum of tariff hikes, and intensifying competition.

Our Rs 1,670 price target is based on SOTP. Risks include elevated cash burn in e- commerce, lower refining and/or petrochemical margins, FCF disappointment, and inadequate returns in new energy investments.
(Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
